content:
• Friday, October 16, 2015
  • WIN

    Windstream: High construction charges creating barriers for carriers, businesses

    • Windstream Holdings (WIN +2.7%) says that charges ILECs are levying for construction are too high and creating problems for both wholesale carriers and businesses wanting to migrate to an IP basis.
    • Businesses are more likely to cancel their order, which could impair competition by threatening existing and new retail customers at a competing carrier, it says.
    • The company's asking the FCC to deal with the issue with a public notice or declaratory ruling.
    • Windstream is looking to reduce $1B in wholesale access costs it pays to deliver services to multisite business customers.
    • FCC filing
     
     
     
     
    | 7:08 PM | 1 Comment
  • CCG

    Campus Crest up 5.6%, agreeing to sale for $1.9B

    • Campus Crest Communities (NYSE:CCG) is up 5.6% after hours, having agreed to a sale to Harrison Street Real Estate Capital for total consideration of $7.03/share -- $1.9B, including debt.
    • That's a 24% premium over today's close. Shares closed up 0.5% today and were trading up to $6.80 after hours.
    • The $7.03 price includes net sale proceeds of up to $0.13/share tied to Campus Crest's sale of its evo Montreal joint venture, and therefore $6.90/share in cash. Exact closing will be dependent on closing of the Montreal sale.
    • The board has unanimously agreed to the sale to Harrison Street.
     
     
     
     
    | 6:53 PM | 7 Comments
  • SFXE

    SFX Entertainment discloses compliance letter from Nasdaq; finishes up 12.5%

    • SFX Entertainment (NASDAQ:SFXE) -- finishing up 12.5% today after CEO Robert Sillerman came in with his new (lower) cash takeover bid -- says in a new filing that it got a written notice from Nasdaq saying it wasn't in listing compliance due to 30 business days under $1/share.
    • The company regains compliance if its closing bid is over $1 for 10 consecutive business days. Of course, today's move means shares closed at $1.17.
    • Shares were up as much as 53% out of the open after news of Sillerman's new bid came in, and largely gave up gains steadily throughout the day.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:50 PM

  • After Hours Gainers / Losers

    • Top gainers, as of 5.25 p.m.: ZFGN +3.2%. SBGL +3.0%. SLCA +2.9%. GWPH +2.3%. CRS +1.8%.
    • Top losers, as of 5.25p.m.: OREX -2.3%. VALE -1.9%. AZN -1.8%. S -1.4%. DXPS -1.4%.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:41 PM | 30 Comments
  • S

    FCC probing four companies in $20B business data market

    • The FCC is probing four companies -- AT&T (T +1%), Verizon (VZ +0.1%), CenturyLink (CTL -0.7%) and Frontier Communications (FTR -1.9%) -- over terms they set for business broadband, the dedicated mission-critical lines that make everything from schools to ATMs work.
    • That's a $20B market, and competitors including Sprint (NYSE:S), Level 3 (NASDAQ:LVLT) and Cogent (NASDAQ:CCOI), along with Amazon.com and others, are complaining about unfair lock-ups with large early termination fees.
    • The FCC has found "potentially unjust and unreasonable practices" that rise to the level of an investigation. It says the four companies it's probing use plans with “a complicated web of all-or-nothing bundling, loyalty and term commitments, complex enforcing penalties” and other provisions, and asked them to respond by Dec. 18.
    • In a mailed statement, industry group USTelecom (of which the four companies are members) says the investigation is a "rear-view mirror" approach. “Although the FCC says that it wants to be a data-driven agency, promote facilities-based competition, and incent broadband investment, it just can’t seem to get beyond its telephone-era mindset when it comes to regulating 20th century legacy services," says USTelecom President Walter McCormick.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:07 PM | 24 Comments

  • Weekly ETF Gainers / Losers

    • Gainers: FXI +2.84%. GDXJ +2.45%. XLU +2.26%. IDU +2.19%. XLV +1.93%.
    • Losers: VXX -7.43%. EWZ -6.02%. OIL -5.16%. USO -4.81%. BNO -4.49%.  
     
     
     
     
    | 4:14 PM
  • SLB

    Schlumberger to cut more jobs in Q4, sees recovery pushed out to 2017

    • Schlumberger (SLB -2.8%) will cut more jobs and consolidate its manufacturing and distribution network, as the company warns of at least another year of pain across the industry, CEO Paal Kibsgaard said in today's earnings conference call.
    • "The likely recovery in our activity levels now seems to be a 2017 event,” the CEO said, as E&P companies have indicated they plan to cut spending next year but have not finalized their budgets, making it difficult for services firms to predict how much further activity could fall.
    • Kibsgaard did not say how many additional jobs are on the block but did say the company will post a Q4 restructuring charge to include severance pay for laid-off workers; SLB took a $390M pre-tax charge in Q2 after cutting headcount by 11K employees.
    • "If they are going make a reduction, it is going to be a sizable reduction to lower the cost structure and given the expected decline - 10% is a reasonable number," Edward Jones analyst Rob Desai says.
    • Nevertheless, analysts are mostly upbeat about SLB; Citigroup reiterates a Buy rating and $81 price target, and FBR maintains its Outperform rating as "SLB has continued to execute impressively, reinforcing the strengths that made it our top pick for 2015."
     
     
     
     
    | 3:27 PM | 6 Comments
  • HON

    Honeywell considering "plenty" of deals topping $5.1B for Elster

    • Honeywell (HON -2%) is looking at sizable acquisitions, perhaps even larger than the $5.1B it paid for Elster, with CFO Tom Szlosek saying at its earnings conference call that "we’ve got a pipeline that’s got plenty of opportunities of that size or bigger.”
    • HON would not wait to integrate Elster before it hunts for more deals, Szlosek said; although a large acquisition is not imminent, the market may "start seeing some further deals being announced," the CFO said.
    • CEO Dave Cote said the Volkswagen scandal is "far from a disaster" for HON, noting sales to VW represent less than 1% of its total and that the company is not dependent on any one vehicle manufacturer.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:11 PM
  • AKS

    AK Steel to idle blast furnace ops at its Ashland Works facility

    • AK Steel (AKS -1.5%) says it will temporarily idle the blast furnace and related steelmaking operations at its Ashland Works facility in Kentucky, laying off as many as 733 workers before year-end.
    • AKS cites "unfairly traded imports of carbon steel that have been flooding our shores," which have cut order intake rates, production rates, shipment volumes and selling prices.
    • AKS says it does not intend to idle the hot-dip galvanizing line at Ashland Works that primarily services automotive customers.
    • SunCoke Energy (SXC -6.1%), which supplies coke to AKS' Ashland and Dearborn blast furnace operations under a long-term contract, says it expects AKS to continue to honor its contract.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:52 PM
  • PWR

    Quanta Services -28% after cutting Q3 EPS guidance

    • Quanta Services (PWR -28.2%) plunges to 52-week lows after lowering Q3 earnings guidance, and warning that Q4 revenues could total ~$200M less than previously expected.
    • For Q3, PWR now expects to report EPS of $0.22-$0.24, well below prior guidance of $0.34-$0.40 as well as the analyst consensus estimate of $0.45; revenues are seen coming in slightly below the midpoint of its $1.9B-$2B guidance and the $1.95B consensus.
    • PWR says the problems are due largely to "the continued competitive environment in small and medium scale electric transmission and delays of certain mainline pipe projects."
     
     
     
     
    | 2:42 PM | 5 Comments
  • TSLA

    SolarCity, SunEdison, other solar stocks under pressure

    • After bouncing strongly from their late-September lows over the last two weeks (a rally in crude prices/energy stocks helped), solar stocks are among the laggards (TAN -2.4%) on a day the Nasdaq and S&P are nearly flat.
    • U.S. firms SolarCity (SCTY -5.3%), SunEdison (SUNE -3.6%), Enphase (ENPH -6%), Sunrun (RUN -2.5%), and RGS Energy (RGSE -6.5%) are among the decliners. Others include SolarEdge (SEDG -4.6%), Trina (TSL -2.3%), JinkoSolar (JKS -2.3%), and SunEdison's TerraForm Global (GLBL -2%) YieldCo.
    • SolarCity reports earnings on Oct. 29, and rival Sunrun on Nov. 12.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:30 PM | 67 Comments
  • HEAR

    Turtle Beach to start shipping HyperSound Clear

    • Turtle Beach (HEAR +5.1%) will begin fulfilling initial orders for its HyperSound Clear hearing aid in the next 3 weeks. The device, which relies on proprietary directional audio IP promised to improve TV/music listening, will carry a $1,675 MSRP.
    • SVP Rodney Schutt: "With nearly 50 million people in the U.S. and 360 million people around the world with hearing loss, and approximately 80% of patients specifically telling their hearing healthcare providers they're having trouble hearing and understanding the TV, we know there's a significant audience of people who can benefit from adding HyperSound Clear into their home entertainment setup."
    • Ahead of the launch, Turtle Beach has inked several HyperSound Clear reseller deals. A manufacturing deal with Foxconn (covers both gaming headsets and HyperSound Clear) was announced last week.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:31 PM | 7 Comments
  • CLF

    Cliffs Natural should eventually resume supplying Essar, analyst says

    • Cliffs Natural Resources (CLF -3.7%) continues to enjoy its role as the most competitive pellet supplier in the U.S., and is likely to eventually return to its position as sole supplier to Essar Algoma despite the current iron ore spat between the companies, J.P. Morgan analyst Michael Gambardella says.
    • Gambardella views Essar's announcement yesterday that it secured “an alternate, interim iron ore supply" as a bargaining tactic as it tries to improve its position amid negotiations with CLF.
    • U.S. Steel (NYSE:X) would be Essar's only other possible supplier within the Great Lakes, but the analyst sees this as unlikely since U.S. Steel also is a competitor to Essar in steel products; Essar’s supplier outside the Great Lakes could be Iron Ore of Canada, in which case Essar "would be paying an unsustainable $30/metric ton incremental shipping cost via the St. Lawrence Seaway."
     
     
     
     
    | 1:12 PM | 9 Comments
  • ORBC

    Orbcomm sets window for 11-satellite launch to finish constellation

    • Satellite firm Orbcomm (ORBC -2%) has set a launch window to deploy 11 OG2 satellites from Cape Canaveral, with the help of SpaceX.
    • The launch is targeted for the next six to eight weeks, on SpaceX's newly upgraded Falcon 9 rocket.
    • SpaceX had helped Orbcomm get OG2 satellites into orbit in July 2014. The new launch will complete Orbcomm's next-generation satellite constellation.
    • Prime contractor Sierra Nevada Corp. is prepping the satellites for shipping to Cape Canaveral at the end of October.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:57 PM
  • AWR

    American State Water cut to Sell at Janney

    • American States Water (AWR -3.1%) is downgraded to Sell from Neutral at Janney, which says shares are trading at a significant premium to other players in the water utility segment.
    • AWR’s low payout ratio of ~55% can support further dividend increases, but the company’s earnings growth during 2015-17 likely will be constrained unless it secures significant new military base contracts, the firm says.
    • A better than expected outcome of the California General Rate Case could have a positive impact on AWR’s earnings, Janney notes.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:57 PM
  • SYF

    BTIG: Buy the spinoff-related dip in Synchrony Financial

    • Synchrony's (SYF -4.2%) earnings beat was driven by increases in loan receivables, purchase volume, and total platform revenue of 12%, 12%, and 9%, respectively, says BTIG's Mark Palmer, reiterating his Buy rating and $42 price target.
    • Combine that growth with improving credit quality - delinquencies and net charge-offs improved by 24 bps and 3 bps, respectively - and management can make a strong case for the stock when the GE spinoff happens next week.
    • Palmer's $42 price target is based on a 14x his 2017 EPS estimate of $3.01. "We believe investors should take advantage of any volatility in the share price driven by technical factors related to the transaction."
    • Previously: Synchrony Financial beats by $0.03, beats on revenue (Oct. 16)
    • Previously: GE beats expectations; announces Synchrony share exchange (Oct. 16)
     
     
     
     
    | 12:55 PM | 2 Comments

  • Midday Gainers / Losers

    • Gainers: YOKU +22%. SFXE +17%. MCUR +13%. ROCK +13%. WB +12%. CVTI +12%. XCO +10%. HTBX +10%. XNPT +10%. CDZI +10%.
    • Losers: ZFGN -37%. TANH -31%. CEMP -30%. PWR -28%. WGBS -25%. CBIO -16%. SAVE -14%. ZINC -13%. MBLX -12%. BGSF -12%.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:45 PM
  • NE

    Noble Corp. signs new drilling contract, Cowen stays optimistic

    • Noble Corp. (NE -1.6%) is lower after providing its latest fleet status report, but analysts at Cowen maintain their Outperform rating and $18 price target on the stock after examining the results.
    • NE inked a new U.S. contract for the Noble Danny Adkins from November to mid-January at a dayrate of $206K, the lowest floater rate in the Gulf of Mexico so far this cycle, but Cowen notes that "given the mismatch in supply and demand, rates could go even lower for short-term work as contractors scramble to add backlog."
    • NE gained a two-month extension on the Noble Houston Colbert in Argentina at a reduced current dayrate of $243K through early April 2016 from $280K and the option at $173K.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:40 PM | 1 Comment
  • DMDA

    Dex Media +3.2%, hires chief restructuring officer for debt talks

    • Dex Media (DXM +3.2%) -- in the midst of discussing a restructuring of senior secured credit -- has named a chief restructuring officer to lead the effort.
    • Andrew D.J. Hede, of Alvarez & Marsal, is taking on the task. In an arrangement with the firm, Hede won't be paid directly by Dex, but Dex will pay Alvarez & Marsal $875/hour for his services.
    • Hede is also chief restructuring officer at Vertis Communications, and has been CEO of Nine West and Jones New York, as well as CEO and CRO of real estate developer Crescent Resources.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:35 PM | 2 Comments
  • SAVE

    52-week low for Spirit Airlines after guidance update and downgrade

    • Spirit Airlines (NASDAQ:SAVE) is down 13.7% on heavy volume after the stock was downgraded by Morgan Stanley to Equal Weight from Overweight.
    • The company also issued a guidance update earlier today. On the key question of prices, Spirit said it expects low pricing in key markets to continue.
    • Q4 unit revenue at the carrier is expected to fall.
    • Capacity growth for 2016 is expected to fall on the low end of the previously-announced 20% to 25% range.
    • Spirit Airlines Investor Update (.pdf)
     
     
     
     
    | 11:57 AM
  • DXI

    Dejour Energy announces 5-for-1 reverse split, name change

    • Dejour Energy (DEJ -2.5%) announces plans for a 5-for-1 reverse stock split effective on or about Oct. 30, a move that will reduce its shares outstanding to ~36.5M from ~182.5M.
    • DEJ also says it will change its name to DXI Energy; its new ticker on the NYSE Amex will be DXI.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:11 AM
  • SINA

    Sina, Weibo jump after Alibaba's bid for Youku fuels M&A hopes

    • Sina (SINA +7.7%) and subsidiary Weibo (WB +14.2%) have soared after acquisition-hungry Alibaba made a $3.6B offer to buy the 82% of Chinese online video provider Youku it doesn't yet own.
    • The move has sparked hopes Alibaba will make a similar bid for Weibo, a company in which it also owns a substantial stake.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:07 AM | 1 Comment
  • GNW

    Genworth tumbles as exec exits

    • "While this was a personal decision by Mr. Klein for another opportunity, we expect it to raise some investor concerns given Genworth’s (GNW -9.1%) depressed stock price,” says KBW's Ryan Krueger, after the resignation of CFO Martin Klein.
    • Already suffering from losses at its long-term care business, Genworth in March also disclosed material weakness in financial reporting for that unit.
    • Klein had also been acting CEO of Genworth during most of 2012.
    • Previously: Genworth CFO leaves; replacement named (Oct. 15)
     
     
     
     
    | 11:07 AM
  • BLOX

    Infoblox gains on Sterne upgrade

    • With shares down sharply from their June highs, Sterne Agee has upgraded Infoblox (BLOX +2.5%) to Buy. The firm's target is $26.
    • Deutsche downgraded Infoblox to Hold last month, while Stifel launched coverage at Buy. Both moves came after the DNS/IP address management hardware firm sold off in the wake of an FQ4 beat and mixed FQ1 guidance.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:54 AM
  • OLED

    Universal Display drops 9.1% on Goldman downgrade

    • Goldman has downgraded Universal Display (NASDAQ:OLED) to Neutral, and cut its target by $10 to $40. Shares have fallen below $36 in response.
    • A week ago, Universal jumped as Cowen reiterated an Outperform, while noting LG OLED TV price cuts - LG's cheapest model is available for $1,799 while supplies last - and Korean government plans to offer fresh incentives (tax benefits, tariff cuts, etc.) for local OLED manufacturing as Chinese and Japanese competition grows.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:48 AM | 11 Comments
  • VZ

    Nomura bullish on wireless picks AT&T, T-Mobile; neutral on VZ, S

    • A review of U.S. wireless operators has Nomura making AT&T (T +0.9%) and T-Mobile (TMUS +2.1%) its top picks, with a more subdued outlook on Verizon (VZ, flat) and Sprint (S -1.1%).
    • The firm has Buy ratings on T and TMUS, and is Neutral on VZ and S.
    • The companies' reactions to a modest growth future vary widely, says Jeffrey Kvaal. Verizon and AT&T are taking two radically different paths into video, while Sprint and T-Mobile go after share gain -- helped by the fact that the incumbents are unlikely to lower their prices.
    • DirecTV synergies should more than offset some share loss at AT&T, and the firm faces modest video subscriber erosion, he says. Meanwhile, T-Mobile should be able to maintain share gains and EBITDA expansion with its aggressive approach.
    • As for Verizon, "visibility beyond a sideways 2016 is limited," and Sprint continues to face a balance sheet strain though its improving network and pricing models have put it "on the brink of a true revival story."
    • Price targets: For AT&T, $39 (closed yesterday at $33.49, 16.5% implied upside); for T-Mobile, $48 (closed yesterday at $39.94, 20% implied upside); for Verizon, $47 (closed yesterday at $44.67, 5% implied upside); for Sprint, $4 (closed yesterday at $4.27).
     
     
     
     
    | 10:33 AM | 17 Comments
  • TWOU

    2U +5.1%; Goldman upgrades after Citron-fueled selloff

    • Goldman's Andre Benjamin has upgraded 2U (NASDAQ:TWOU) to Buy four days after shares dived due to a bearish Citron Research report. His target has been cut by $4 to $36.
    • Benjamin forecasts positive EBITDA by 2017, and expects to see more evidence of an improving deal pipeline. The call comes ahead of 2U's Oct. 26 Q3 report.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:21 AM | 3 Comments
  • DISCA

    Discovery Communications -1.6% as Barclays downgrades to Equal Weight

    • Discovery Communications (NASDAQ:DISCA) is off 1.6% as Barclays cuts its rating to Equal Weight.
    • The firm's Kannan Venkateshwar cut Barclays' price target on Discovery to $30, from $34. Shares closed yesterday at $28.86.
    • There's a long timeline for growth built into its operating leverage, he says. The company now sees EBITDA margins at Eurosport and its over-the-top platform at 5-15% by 2018, compared with Barclays expectations of almost 18%, and "we believe the lowered guidance is likely driven by more than just conservatism."
    • He also expects Discovery to cut repurchases even at a time when they "could actually be accretive."
     
     
     
     
    | 10:11 AM
  • MAT

    Mattel boosted by confident tone on earnings call

    • Mattel (NASDAQ:MAT) opens with a quick 6% pop after a bouncy post-earnings after-hours session last night.
    • Though the company missed with its Q3 profit mark, during the earnings conference call some positive trends were highlighted by management.
    • Mattel's performance in China hasn't missed a beat, said CEO Chris Sinclar. He also tipped that emerging markets look set for a huge upside in the coming months.
    • The toy company also backed up its 2015 guidance, despite the Q3 shortfall. Q4 revenue is seen as higher than the Q3 tally.
    • Mattel earnings call transcript
    • Previously: Mattel slides 7% after reporting weak numbers in Q3 (Oct. 15 2015)
    • Previously: Mattel higher in spite of Q3 miss; strong dollar a big headwind (updated) (Oct. 15 2015)
     
     
     
     
    | 9:58 AM | 13 Comments
  • EGC

    Energy XXI CEO Schiller stripped of chairman title

    • Energy XXI CEO (EXXI +1.8%) John Schiller is removed as chairman following an internal investigation that found he borrowed money from vendors and received a personal loan from a board member.
    • EXXI's board now says the CEO and Chairman positions should no longer be held by one person to “enhance communication” between board members and management and ensure compliance with company policies and procedures.
    • Board member James LaChance is named the new Chairman; Schiller remains President and CEO of the company.
     
     
     
     
    | 9:55 AM | 3 Comments
  • FEYE

    D.A. Davidson starts FireEye at Buy, sees several catalysts

    • D.A. Davidson has launched coverage on FireEye (FEYE +1.2%) with a Buy rating and $51 target.
    • The firm cites several potential catalysts, including "potential product growth reacceleration, continued market penetration with FEYE's endpoint solution, more market awareness and traction with strategic partners (i.e. Visa), and demonstrable progress with operating leverage and a defined path to generating positive cash flow." Imperial Capital forecast in August FireEye would achieve breakeven op. cash flow this year and see free cash flow of -$50M (improved from 2014).
    • The launch follows a cautious Deutsche note issued after attending FireEye's annual Cyber Defense Summit. Stifel provided a more positive reaction. Shares are only down slightly YTD, but 45% below a June high of $55.33 and 69% below a March 2014 peak of $97.35.
     
     
     
     
    | 9:49 AM
  • BX

    Blackstone upgraded post-earnings at Oppenheimer

    • Headline earnings (known as "economic net income") were pretty ugly for Blackstone (BX +1.6%) in Q3, but analyst Chris Kotowski has always been more concerned with cash earnings (known as "distributable earnings"), and the company came pretty close to meeting estimates on that front.
    • Economic net income is volatile and non-cash, providing just a short-term view on true earnings potential, says Kotowski.
    • "In absolute terms, [the stock is] very compelling at this valuation since the cash earnings outlook remains very strong."
    • He upgrades to Outperform with $38 price target (about 12% above last night's close).
    • Previously: Stock price declines hit Blackstone results (Oct. 15)
    • Previously: Blackstone misses by $0.05, revenue in-line (Oct. 15)
     
     
     
     
    | 9:46 AM | 7 Comments
  • TMUS

    T-Mobile headed to Nasdaq

    • T-Mobile (NASDAQ:TMUS) is transferring its listing from the NYSE to Nasdaq effective after the close Oct. 26.
    • Its symbol will continue to be TMUS for the common stock, and TMUSP for preferred stock.
    • T-Mobile expects the move will be seamless for current shareholders.
    • Shares are up 1.6% today; YTD the stock has appreciated 50.5%.
    • Previously: T-Mobile in pole position as smaller carriers start bailing out of auction (Oct. 15 2015)
    • Previously: T-Mobile brings back popular family-plan promotion (Oct. 14 2015)
     
     
     
     
    | 9:43 AM | 2 Comments
  • BOX

    Box gains on JPMorgan upgrade

    • Believing risk/reward has improved with shares down 33% since February, JPMorgan's Mark Murphy has upgraded Box (BOX +2.5%) to Overweight, while cutting his target by $3 to $18.
    • Murphy also highlights recent insider buying, notes a lockup expiration has come and gone, and argues investors may be underestimating the importance of the IBM partnership.
     
     
     
     
    | 9:36 AM | 2 Comments
  • XSPA

    Vringo buys wireless charging firm, rugged computer maker; shares +31.2%

    • Vringo (VRNG) has bought a holding company (named IDG) consisting of fliCharge, a wireless charging technology developer, and Group Mobile, a maker of rugged PCs, tablets, and handheld computers. The company is issuing preferred stock convertible into common shares equal to 11.4% of the combined company's equity.
    • fliCharge's technology enables the simultaneous charging of multiple devices on the same pad regardless of position or power needs. Vringo asserts fliCharge is "commercializing, partnering or developing products in numerous markets including automotive, education, office, healthcare, power tools and vaporizers." Group Mobile's customers include enterprises, military suppliers, small businesses, and individuals.
    • Vringo CEO Andrew Perlman: "Our existing patent licensing and litigation strategy remains intact and on track. We believe this acquisition offers diversification to our shareholders and additional licensing opportunities." The move comes shortly after the Supreme Court declined to review an adverse appeals court ruling regarding Vringo's suit against Google.
    • Vringo has risen to $0.50 premarket.
    • Update: More details on the acquisitions can be found in a Vringo presentation (.pdf). IDG had 2014 revenue of $7M+. fliCharge's charging pads are said to be "offered in various Ford, Chrysler, and Toyota models" through a partnership with an unnamed tier-1 auto supplier. A partnership also exists with "smart furniture solutions" maker Bretford. (hat tip: SA commenter Seppo Sahrakorpi). Vringo has pared its gains: Shares are now up 7.7%.
     
     
     
     
    | 9:24 AM | 68 Comments

  • Premarket Gainers / Losers as of 9:10 am

    • Gainers: SFXE +41%. YOKU +23%. PTCT +11%. TWOU +8%. WB +7%.
    • Losers: ZFGN -31%. WGBS -26%. CEMP -16%. PWR -10%. WYNN -9%.
     
     
     
     
    | 9:14 AM
  • YOKU

    Youku Tudou up 24% following Alibaba buyout offer

    • Youku Tudou (NYSE:YOKU) is up 23.8% premarket following Alibaba's (NYSE:BABA) offer to buy the rest of the company -- "China's YouTube" -- at a 30%-plus premium.
    • Key Youku shareholders -- including founder and CEO Victor Koo and Chengwei Capital -- have entered a support agreement to vote their shares in favor of the $3.6B cash offer, which values Youku at $4.2B.
    • The board is forming a committee of (a pair of) disinterested directors to consider the deal.
    • BABA is up 0.5% premarket.
     
     
     
     
    | 9:12 AM | 9 Comments
  • CEMP

    Late-stage study shows Cempra's solithromycin on par with moxifloxacin but adverse events almost three times as high; shares slump 14% premarket

    • Cempra (NASDAQ:CEMP) is down 14% premarket on robust volume in response to its announcement of results from its Phase 3 clinical trial, called Solitaire-IV, evaluating lead product solithromycin for the treatment of community-acquired bacterial pneumonia (CABP).
    • In the intent-to-treat population, solithromycin demonstrated non-inferiority (no worse than) to moxifloxacin (Bayer's Avelox) on several measures. Treatment-related adverse events, however, were substantially higher with solithromycin (34.3%) than moxifloxacin (13.1%), principally due to a higher number of infusion site reactions, a known side effect of solithromycin's class of drugs (macrolides) when administered intravenously. Serious adverse events were comparable at 6.9% and 5.4%, respectively.
    • Fast Track- and Qualified Infectious Disease Product-tagged solithromycin is a next-generation antibiotic called a fluoroketolide, a member of a class of drugs that has shown effectiveness against drug-resistant bacteria because of their ability to bind to two sites on the bacterial ribosome.
    • The analysis of the results is ongoing. The company intends to present additional data from Solitaire-IV and pooled data from its two Phase 3s at future medical conferences.
     
     
     
     
    | 9:10 AM | 30 Comments
  • PGR

    Progressive misses by $0.01, beats on revenue

    • Progressive (NYSE:PGR): Q3 EPS of $0.47 misses by $0.01.
    • Revenue of $5.41B (+14.4% Y/Y) beats by $140M.
    • Shares +3.68% PM.
     
     
     
     
    | 9:07 AM
  • LULU

    Lululemon higher after Credit Suisse endorses

    • Lululemon (NASDAQ:LULU) is on watch after catching a key upgrade from Credit Suisse to Outperform from Neutral.
    • The investment firm sets a price target of $64 on the apparel stock.
    • LULU +2.21% premarket to $53.68.
     
     
     
     
    | 8:30 AM
  • PTCT

    Investors see the positives in PTC's failed Phase 3 Translarna study; shares up 14% premarket

    • Investors are taking a surprisingly positive view of the data from PTC Therapeutics' (NASDAQ:PTCT) Phase 3 clinical trial assessing Translarna (ataluren) for the treatment of nonsense mutation Duchenne muscular dystrophy (nmDMD). Shares are up 14% premarket on robust volume.
    • The study failed to achieve its primary efficacy endpoint, but the company slashed through the data and identified a subgroup of patients (6MWT of 300 -400 meters) that may benefit.
    • Previously: Trading in PTC Therapeutics halted pending news; Translarna flunks late-stage study in DMD (Oct. 15)

    Hugo Boss falls sharply after guidance cut

    • Shares of Hugo Boss (OTCPK:BOSSY) were rocked in Frankfurt trading after the company cut sales and profit guidance for 2015.

    • W.W. Grainger (NYSE:GWW) reports organic sales were flat Y/Y in Q3.

    GE beats expectations; announces Synchrony share exchange

    • Capping a dramatic portfolio reshaping quarter, General Electric (NYSE:GE) posted adjusted profit of $2.9B (+12% Y/Y), or $0.29 per share, beating estimates.
    • Industrial operating profit grew 5% to $4.5B in the quarter, while gains from aviation, transport and appliances helped offset the oil and gas sector.
    • GE also said it will also launch a share exchange for Synchrony Financial (NYSE:SYF) next week, which will significantly reduce its outstanding share count.

  • ZFGN

    FDA places Zafgen's late-stage beloranib study on partial clinical hold; shares off 26% premarket

    • Zafgen (NASDAQ:ZFGN) is down 26% premarket on light volume in response to its announcement that the FDA has placed its Phase 3 study, ZAF-311, evaluating lead product candidate beloranib in obese patients wit Prader-Willi syndrome (PWS) on partial clinical hold until the death of the previously reported trial participant is fully investigated. It has been confirmed that the patient was receiving beloranib. Patients currently participating in ZAF-311 will be screened for existing thrombotic disease prior to receiving further study drug (beloranib) and will be regularly monitored through the end of the trial. Since the study is almost complete, the company expects to report top-line data in Q1.
    • It also expects to initiate another Phase 3 study of beloranib in PWS, ZAF-312, after ZAF-311 in completed and a full assessment of the drug candidate's safety and efficacy has been performed by the FDA.
    • Similar screening and monitoring is being considered for the ongoing Phase 2b trial, ZAF-203, evaluating beloranib in obese patients with type 2 diabetes.
    • The company will host a conference call this morning at 8:30 am ET to discuss the situation.
     
     
     
     
    | 7:26 AM | 8 Comments
